questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with complaints of painless swelling in her external genitalia. On examination of the vulva, a tense, fluctuant mass is palpable at the posterior vaginal introitus, measuring approximately 3 cm in diameter (as shown below). No signs of inflammation are present. Which of the following is the management of this condition?

options.label: C
options.text: Hot compress over the area and analgesics

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with fever and intense pain in her vulvar region, reporting that she is unable to walk or sit comfortably. On examination, the physician discovered a red, edematous, unilateral swelling beneath the posterior half of the patient's labium majus which was tender on touch. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 28-year-old woman presents to the clinic with infertility. She reports a history of treatment for pulmonary tuberculosis in adolescence. What is the most likely route of spread of infection from the primary site to her pelvic organs leading to infertility?
Which of the following is the most common site for pelvic tuberculosis?
Which of the following statements is true?

options.label: A
options.text: Hysterosalpingography is contraindicated in genital tuberculosis

options.label: B
options.text: Infertility is the most common complication in untreated pelvic tuberculosis

options.label: C
options.text: Bilateral cornual block is a sign of genital tuberculosis

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with a history of infertility and chronic pelvic pain. Hysterosalpingography (HSG) is performed to evaluate her reproductive anatomy. Which of the following HSG findings is characteristic of female genital TB?
A 30-year-old female presents with infertility and is diagnosed with tuberculosis (TB) of the fallopian tubes. Without antitubercular treatment (ATT), which of the following statements is true?

options.label: A
options.text: Hysterosalpingography (HSG) can be done to check tubal patency.

options.label: B
options.text: Direct spread of TB may occur from the fallopian tubes to the uterus.

options.label: C
options.text: Hematogenous spread will occur from the fallopian tubes to the uterus.

options.label: D
options.text: TB will resolve on its own without treatment.

questions.correct_answer: B. Direct spread of TB may occur from the fallopian tubes to the uterus.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman presents with complaints of infertility and chronic lower abdominal pain for the past year. She mentions recent unintentional weight loss and occasional night sweats. Her menstrual cycles have been regular, but she has experienced heavier-than-usual periods over the past six months. Considering her symptoms and clinical history, the clinician suspects endometrial tuberculosis and decides to perform an endometrial biopsy for diagnosis. Which is the best time to perform an endometrial biopsy to diagnose endometrial tuberculosis?

options.label: D
options.text: Any time during the menstrual cycle

questions.correct_answer: C. During the late premenstrual phase

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with chronic cough, weight loss, and night sweats, and was initially diagnosed as pulmonary tuberculosis. She now complains of menstrual irregularities and infertility. Upon further investigation, the following radiograph (shown below) is observed. What is the most likely explanation for her current condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Direct extension of pulmonary TB to the uterus

options.label: B
options.text: Secondary genital TB due to hematogenous spread from pulmonary TB

options.label: C
options.text: Reactivation of latent TB in the uterus

options.label: D
options.text: Direct extension from peritoneum to the uterus

questions.correct_answer: B. Secondary genital TB due to hematogenous spread from pulmonary TB

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman presents with a 6-month history of secondary amenorrhea and pelvic pain. She reports intermittent fever and significant weight loss over the past few months. On physical examination, there is tenderness in the lower abdomen, and an adnexal mass is palpated. Given these findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
Which of the following is the most accurate statement regarding the role of ultrasonography (USG) and laparoscopy in the diagnosis of genital tuberculosis (TB) in women?

options.label: A
options.text: USG can definitively diagnose genital TB by detecting specific tuberculous lesions in the pelvic organs.

options.label: B
options.text: Laparoscopy is mainly used to assess the extent of tubal damage in genital TB, and it allows for direct visualization and biopsy of the affected tissues.

options.label: C
options.text: USG is more effective than laparoscopy in identifying tubal obstruction caused by genital TB.

options.label: D
options.text: Both USG and laparoscopy are equally effective in diagnosing genital TB and can be used interchangeably.

questions.correct_answer: B. Laparoscopy is mainly used to assess the extent of tubal damage in genital TB, and it allows for direct visualization and biopsy of the affected tissues.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with a history of chronic pelvic pain, irregular menstrual cycles, and a two-year history of primary infertility. Upon evaluation, she is diagnosed with genital tuberculosis (TB). Considering the diagnosis, which of the following statements accurately describes the treatment approach for her condition, including both medical and surgical options?

options.label: A
options.text: Medical treatment alone, consisting of antitubercular therapy for 6–9 months, is typically sufficient to restore fertility in all cases of genital TB.

options.label: B
options.text: Surgical intervention is usually needed in genital TB, as most cases do not resolve with antitubercular therapy alone.

options.label: C
options.text: Antitubercular therapy is the first-line treatment, but surgery may be necessary in cases of extensive adhesions, tubal blockages, or when there is a suspicion of an abscess.

options.label: D
options.text: The main treatment for genital TB is surgical removal of the affected reproductive organs, followed by a short course of antitubercular therapy.

questions.correct_answer: C. Antitubercular therapy is the first-line treatment, but surgery may be necessary in cases of extensive adhesions, tubal blockages, or when there is a suspicion of an abscess.
